div.p: Greetings. I arrived in Basel today, dearest Bullinger, by the grace of Christ quite comfortably, except that my left foot still retains its swelling, which I bear moderately until it gradually subsides. I was received by the brothers, Master Mykonius and Gast, very kindly and was taken home by the printer Hervagius, where I will stay for a while until divine providence assigns me to a certain place. One thing troubles me greatly, that here, as I had hoped, I find no letters and am still forced to be uncertain about the colleagues I left behind, my wife, and children. But this trouble must also be endured.

I beg you to send the enclosed letters to Constance at the first opportunity offered by a messenger. Conrad, my companion, conducted himself excellently. May the Lord repay him. I am not permitted to write more now. I will await what you write about the people of Bern, although I think it wise to deliberate with myself for a while about what would benefit not only me but also the cause of Christ.
Farewell excellently. Greetings to your most honorable household and to all the brothers there.
W(olfgang) Musculus, yours in the Lord.
